questions.question: If the mass of one of two attracting objects is doubled, and the other stays the same, the gravitational force between them:
questions.explanation: $F \propto m_1$, so doubling one mass doubles the force.

questions.question: Planet X has twice the mass of Earth and the same radius. What is the acceleration due to gravity on Planet X? (Use $g_{Earth} = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: $g \propto M$ at constant radius, so $g_X = 2 \times 10 = 20$ m/s².

questions.question: Planet Y has the same mass as Earth but twice the radius. What is the acceleration due to gravity on Planet Y? (Use $g_{Earth} = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)
Two masses experience a force $F$. If the distance between them is cut in half ($r/2$), the new force is:
questions.explanation: $F \propto 1/r^2$, so halving distance quadruples the force.

questions.question: Calculate the gravitational force between a $100 \text{ kg}$ mass and a $1000 \text{ kg}$ mass separated by $10 \text{ m}$. (Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \text{ N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2$)
If the Earth were to shrink to half its current radius without losing any mass, your weight on the surface would:
questions.explanation: $g \propto 1/R^2$, so halving radius quadruples $g$ and your weight.

questions.question: How does the orbital speed of a satellite change as its distance from the planet increases?
options: The speed doubles every time the radius doubles.
questions.explanation: $v = \sqrt{GM/r}$, so speed decreases as distance increases.

questions.question: Why do astronauts inside the International Space Station (ISS) appear weightless?
options: There is no gravity at that altitude.
They are in a state of continuous free fall along with their spacecraft.
The air pressure inside the station counteracts gravity.
They are too far away from Earth's center for gravity to act.
questions.explanation: Astronauts and ISS are in continuous free fall together, creating apparent weightlessness.

questions.question: A 100 kg satellite and a 500 kg satellite are in the same circular orbit. How do their orbital speeds compare?
options: The 500 kg satellite moves faster because it is more massive.
The 100 kg satellite moves faster because it is lighter.
They have the same orbital speed because mass cancels out in the calculation.
It depends on which satellite was launched first.
questions.explanation: Orbital speed $v = \sqrt{GM/r}$ is independent of satellite mass.

questions.question: Kepler's Third Law for circular orbits states that the square of the period ($T^2$) is proportional to:
options: The square root of the radius ($\sqrt{r}$).
